pullRequest.title: Update invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecode handlers
pullRequest.bodyText:
This changeset updates the handling of invokedynamic and invokehandle
bytecodes in preparation for migrating to the OpenJDK MethodHandle
implementation. The changes are not enabled by default, and are guarded
in the macro J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE.
This implementation can handle both resolved and unresolved
invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecodes.
Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan nubhuiyan@ibm.com

beforeCommit.message:
Update invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecode handlers

This changeset updates the handling of invokedynamic and invokehandle
bytecodes in preparation for migrating to the AdoptOpenJDK MethodHandle
implementation. The changes are not enabled by default, and are guarded
in the macro J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE.

This implementation can handle both resolved and unresolved
invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecodes.

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

nodes.bodyText: invokeCache is unlikely to be null based on the way it's calculated. The exception is unnecessary. If it's null, there will be a functional issue and we'll crash trying to access its member variable.
Same here.
owningMethod should be this. We're looking at invokedynamic bytecode of this resolved method.
No need to fail compilation here.
Reading constant pool entries does require a VM access. I think the VM access including the original one can be removed.
We should use isUnresolvedCallSiteTableEntry to see if entry is unresolved.
I think the dummy invoke is the only thing different from current implementation, other code can be shared
VM access is needed to call targetMethodFromMemberName with object reference.
Comments for getResolvedDynamicMethod apply here
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -6802,6 +6835,39 @@ TR_ResolvedJ9Method::getResolvedHandleMethod(TR::Compilation * comp, I_32 cpInde
 #else
    TR_ResolvedMethod *result = NULL;
 
+#if defined(J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE)

nodes.bodyText: Same here, should use isUnresolvedMethodTypeTableEntry
invokeCache will never be null, it's just a pointer into the side table. We should use isUnresolvedCallSiteTableEntry
Setting null flag on a node means that the node produce null value at runtime, which is wrong.
Same here.
The bit vector is used in the openj9 implementation to transform the call later. The new implementation doesn't need it.

beforeCommit.message:
Update invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecode handlers

This changeset updates the handling of invokedynamic and invokehandle
bytecodes in preparation for migrating to the OpenJDK MethodHandle
implementation. The changes are not enabled by default, and are guarded
in the macro J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE.

This implementation can handle both resolved and unresolved
invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecodes.

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

afterCommit.message:
Lookup InvokeCacheEntry from CS and MT tables

CS - Call Site Table
MT - Method Type Table

Looking up InvokeCacheEntry from CS and MT tables
is necessary for the OpenJDK MethodHandle implementation.
InvokeCacheEntry consists of 2 entries per call site. CS table
lookup will be used for invokeDynamic, and MT table lookup will
be used for invokeHandle.

Also-by: Jack Lu <Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

nodes.bodyText: Same problem here

There are a lot of duplication of this code. Can we add a few APIs to get address of member name/appendix and hide the implementation detail of the side table? Something like
memberNameAddressFromInvokeDynamicSideTable(int32_t callSiteIndex)
appendixAddressFromInvokeDynamicSideTable(int32_t callSiteIndex)
memberNameAddressFromInvokeHandleSideTable(int32_t cpIndex)
appendixAddressFromInvokeHandleSideTable(int32_t cpIndex)

nodes.bodyText: This function should return address of the object reference in the table. invokeCache->target is the actual object reference, we should return  &invokeCache->target. Like methodTypeTableEntryAddress and callSiteTableEntryAddress, the return type void *
Same here
Same here
Same here
Should this be ||? Also, I don't think we need knot to inline the adapter method. Adapter method is static and is known if the callsite is resolved.

If appendixAddressFromInvokeDynamicSideTable returns the address instead of the appendix object reference, we don't need to take the address of it.
If knot is null, just push unknown operand.

If memberNameAddressFromInvokeDynamicSideTable returns an address, we need to dereference the address to get the MemberName. Or you can add a function targetMethodFromMemberNameAt to take address of MemberName, and return you the target method. Inside targetMethodFromMemberNameAt, you need to acquire vm access
Comments for visitInvokedynamic apply to visitInvokehandle
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -621,13 +651,59 @@ InterpreterEmulator::visitInvokedynamic()
 
       TR_CallSite *callsite = new (comp()->trHeapMemory()) TR_J9MethodHandleCallSite(_calltarget->_calleeMethod, callNodeTreeTop,   parent,
                                                                         callNode, interfaceMethod, resolvedMethod->classOfMethod(),
-                                                                        -1, cpIndex, resolvedMethod,
+                                                                        -1, callSiteIndex, resolvedMethod,
                                                                         resolvedSymbol, isIndirectCall, isInterface, *_newBCInfo, comp(),
                                                                         _recursionDepth, allconsts);
 
       findTargetAndUpdateInfoForCallsite(callsite);
       }
+#endif //J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE
+   }
+
+#if defined(J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE)
+void
+InterpreterEmulator::visitInvokehandle()

nodes.bodyText: If knot is null, we still need to push an operand (unknown operand) to maintain the right stack shape.

afterCommit.message:
Fix method arg count store for invokeBasic

The VM uses the value stored in VMThread.tempSlot to determine
the location of the receiver object in the stack for the
signature-polymorphic calls to invokeBasic, accessing the entry
at _sp[VMThread.tempSlot].
However, the JIT was storing the number of args in the
invokeBasic call into VMThread.tempSlot, which assumes each arg
for the invokeBasic call occupies one stack slot. This was not
the case for data types that occupied more than one stack slot,
for example, dconst.

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

nodes.bodyText: It would be instructive to have a brief comment here describing what this lowering is doing rather than having to grok the code.  Presumably, this is a meta-argument for invokeBasic?

The logic in the invokeHandle and invokeDynamic cases is 95% identical.  Can you think of a way of combining the internals into a shared function without impacting understanding?    I'm just thinking of the code footprint here...
Just curious why there is so much whitespace preceding the function name.  It doesn't match the style of the surrounding code.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -794,6 +794,41 @@ class TR_J9VMBase : public TR_FrontEnd
     *    VM access is not required
     */
    TR_OpaqueMethodBlock* targetMethodFromMethodHandle(TR::Compilation* comp, TR::KnownObjectTable::Index objIndex);
+
+   /**
+    * \brief
+    *    Get the signature For MethodHandle.linkToStatic call for unresolved invokehandle
+    *
+    *    For unresolved invokeHandle, we do not know the adapter method at
+    *    compile time. The call is expressed as a call to the signature-polymorphic
+    *    MethodHandle.linkToStatic method. In addition to the arguments of the original call,
+    *    we need to provide the target and appendix objects as the last two arguments, in addition
+    *    to the MethodHandle object as the first argument. Therefore, we need to modify the
+    *    signature of the original call and adapt it to accept three extra arguments.
+    *
+    * \param comp the current compilation
+    * \param romMethodSignature the ROM Method signature to be processed
+    * \return char * the signature for linkToStatic
+    */
+   char *                getSignatureForLinkToStaticForInvokeHandle(TR::Compilation* comp, J9UTF8* romMethodSignature);

nodes.bodyText: Just curious why there is so much whitespace preceding the function name.  It doesn't match the style of the surrounding code.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -794,6 +794,41 @@ class TR_J9VMBase : public TR_FrontEnd
     *    VM access is not required
     */
    TR_OpaqueMethodBlock* targetMethodFromMethodHandle(TR::Compilation* comp, TR::KnownObjectTable::Index objIndex);
+
+   /**
+    * \brief
+    *    Get the signature For MethodHandle.linkToStatic call for unresolved invokehandle
+    *
+    *    For unresolved invokeHandle, we do not know the adapter method at
+    *    compile time. The call is expressed as a call to the signature-polymorphic
+    *    MethodHandle.linkToStatic method. In addition to the arguments of the original call,
+    *    we need to provide the target and appendix objects as the last two arguments, in addition
+    *    to the MethodHandle object as the first argument. Therefore, we need to modify the
+    *    signature of the original call and adapt it to accept three extra arguments.
+    *
+    * \param comp the current compilation
+    * \param romMethodSignature the ROM Method signature to be processed
+    * \return char * the signature for linkToStatic
+    */
+   char *                getSignatureForLinkToStaticForInvokeHandle(TR::Compilation* comp, J9UTF8* romMethodSignature);
+
+
+   /**
+    * \brief
+    *    Get the signature for MethodHandle.linkToStatic call for unresolved invokedynamic
+    *
+    *    For unresolved invokeDynamic, we do not know the adapter method at
+    *    compile time. The call is expressed as a call to the signature-polymorphic
+    *    MethodHandle.linkToStatic method. In addition to the arguments of the original call,
+    *    we need to provide the target and appendix objects as the last two arguments.
+    *    Therefore, we need to modify the signature of the original call and adapt it to accept
+    *    the two extra arguments.
+    *
+    * \param comp the current compilation
+    * \param romMethodSignature the ROM Method signature to be processed
+    * \return char * the signature for linkToStatic
+    */
+   char *                getSignatureForLinkToStaticForInvokeDynamic(TR::Compilation* comp, J9UTF8* romMethodSignature);

commit.message:
Update invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecode handlers

This changeset updates the handling of invokedynamic and invokehandle
bytecodes in preparation for migrating to the OpenJDK MethodHandle
implementation. The changes are not enabled by default, and are guarded
in the macro J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE.

This implementation can handle both resolved and unresolved
invokedynamic and invokehandle bytecodes.

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

Lookup InvokeCacheEntry from CS and MT tables

CS - Call Site Table
MT - Method Type Table

Looking up InvokeCacheEntry from CS and MT tables
is necessary for the OpenJDK MethodHandle implementation.
InvokeCacheEntry consists of 2 entries per call site. CS table
lookup will be used for invokeDynamic, and MT table lookup will
be used for invokeHandle.

Also-by: Jack Lu <Jack.S.Lu@ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

Update invokeCache entry look-up to use single-slot design

For invokeDynamic and invokeHandle side table entries in
callSiteTable and invokeCache tables respectively, the
invoke cache entries are now a 2-element array consisting of:
invokeCacheArray[0]= member name object
invokeCacheArray[1]= appendix object.

IlGen, inliner, symRefTab, etc.  has been updated to use this
design.

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

Fix method arg count store for invokeBasic

The VM uses the value stored in VMThread.tempSlot to determine
the location of the receiver object in the stack for the
signature-polymorphic calls to invokeBasic, accessing the entry
at _sp[VMThread.tempSlot].
However, the JIT was storing the number of args in the
invokeBasic call into VMThread.tempSlot, which assumes each arg
for the invokeBasic call occupies one stack slot. This was not
the case for data types that occupied more than one stack slot,
for example, doubles.

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

Update copyright dates

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

beforeCommit.message:
Update copyright dates

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

afterCommit.message:
Update copyright dates

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

nodes.bodyText:
So we're looking up the side table entry twice, one for creating targetMethodSymRef, one from loadFromSideTableForInvokeDynamic, resolution of the entry might change between the two look up. You may get a method symref for linkToStatic but with number of arguments loaded for resolved case.
If targetMethodSymRef is linkToStatic, we should check if the method takes one more argument than needed to see if the method symbol is created for unresolved case. Then load arguments accordingly.
Can we use macros for array index for appendix object and MemberName instead of harding code them? The macro can be put into env/JSR292Methods.h
Since we're taking an object ref, VM access should have been acquired by the caller. We need an assert here to ensure that

commit.message:
Misc. cleanup work in OpenJDK MH bytecode handler implementation

This changeset includes the following:
* Reduced code duplication in invokeDynamic and invokeHandle
  bytecode handlers in  ILGen and Inliner
* Use of macros to index into invokeCacheArray
* Add/assert VM access where required

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

beforeCommit.message:
Update mechanism for checking invokedynamic/handle is resolved

When unresolved, the adapter method symbol constructed is
linkToStatic, which requires 2 additional args on top of
the original ROM Method parameters for invokedynamic and
3 additional args in the case of invokehandle. In both
cases, when resolved, there would be one less invoke cache
array element load required as opposed to the unresolved
case. This way of checking whether we are dealing with
an unresolved case would ensure that the right number of
objects are pushed even if resolution happens in between
creating the target method and loading the invoke cache
elements.

The new mechanism introduces the following functions
in TR_ResolvedJ9Method:
* numberOfRomMethodParametersAtCallSiteIndex
* numberOfRomMethodParametersAtCPIndex
* numberOfParametersInSignature
These functions are used to obtain the number of parameters
from the ROM method and then compared to the number of
parameters of the target method sym ref created. The
difference would determine the number of arguments that
are to be pushed.

Also part of this changeset are some comments specifying
parts of the new bytecode handler implementation that would
not work in AOT and/or JITServer.

Signed-off-by: Nazim Bhuiyan <nubhuiyan@ibm.com>

afterCommit.message:
Update mechanism for checking invokedynamic/handle is resolved

When unresolved, the adapter method symbol constructed is
linkToStatic, which requires 2 additional args on top of
the original ROM Method parameters for invokedynamic and
3 additional args in the case of invokehandle. In both
cases, when resolved, there would be one less invoke cache
array element load required as opposed to the unresolved
case. This way of checking whether we are dealing with
an unresolved case would ensure that the right number of
objects are pushed even if resolution happens in between
creating the target method and loading the invoke cache
elements.

The new mechanism relies on passing a pointer to a boolean
variable from ILGen that gets set before accessing the call
site table or constant pool table.

Also part of this changeset are some comments specifying
parts of the new bytecode handler implementation that would
not work in AOT and/or JITServer.

nodes.bodyText: Can you be more specific about "target"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -798,6 +798,41 @@ class TR_J9VMBase : public TR_FrontEnd
     *    VM access is not required
     */
    TR_OpaqueMethodBlock* targetMethodFromMethodHandle(TR::Compilation* comp, TR::KnownObjectTable::Index objIndex);
+
+   /**
+    * \brief
+    *    Get the signature For MethodHandle.linkToStatic call for unresolved invokehandle
+    *
+    *    For unresolved invokeHandle, we do not know the adapter method at
+    *    compile time. The call is expressed as a call to the signature-polymorphic
+    *    MethodHandle.linkToStatic method. In addition to the arguments of the original call,
+    *    we need to provide the target and appendix objects as the last two arguments, in addition
+    *    to the MethodHandle object as the first argument. Therefore, we need to modify the
+    *    signature of the original call and adapt it to accept three extra arguments.
+    *
+    * \param comp the current compilation
+    * \param romMethodSignature the ROM Method signature to be processed
+    * \return char * the signature for linkToStatic
+    */
+   char * getSignatureForLinkToStaticForInvokeHandle(TR::Compilation* comp, J9UTF8* romMethodSignature);
+
+
+   /**
+    * \brief
+    *    Get the signature for MethodHandle.linkToStatic call for unresolved invokedynamic
+    *
+    *    For unresolved invokeDynamic, we do not know the adapter method at
+    *    compile time. The call is expressed as a call to the signature-polymorphic
+    *    MethodHandle.linkToStatic method. In addition to the arguments of the original call,
+    *    we need to provide the target and appendix objects as the last two arguments.

nodes.bodyText: Can we move all OJDK code inside one if defined for code cleanness? It's also worth to add a brief comment why the method for unresolved case is different. Same applies to change in getResolvedHandleMethod
Can getSignatureForLinkToStaticForInvokeDynamic return the length of the signature?
Can you be more specific in what target object is? And when it is required?
Is this the static address of the array? Or the java object reference?
Opcode for indirect field load and indirect array load can be different, although for address type it's the same, we should still use il.opCodeForIndirectArrayLoad
Can you add more comments to explain what this code does?
It's worth to add a comments to show the call generated for resolved and unresolved case
We shouldn't pass true to getOrCreateIndex as appendix element is not an array
We should also return for JITServer. Same for visitInvokehandle

afterCommit.message:
Update mechanism for checking invokedynamic/handle is resolved

When unresolved, the adapter method symbol constructed is
linkToStatic, which requires 2 additional args on top of

3 additional args in the case of invokehandle. In both

nodes.bodyText: We should mention it is the number of arg slots minus the receiver slot
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1074,9 +1074,23 @@ J9::CodeGenerator::lowerTreeIfNeeded(
        !node->getSymbol()->castToMethodSymbol()->isHelper() &&
        (node->getSymbol()->castToMethodSymbol()->getRecognizedMethod() == TR::java_lang_invoke_MethodHandle_invokeBasic))
       {
+      // invokeBasic is signature-polymorphic, so the location of the method handle receiver object on the stack will depend
+      // on the number of arguments in the invokeBasic call. Therefore, the number of stack slots used by the args of the call

nodes.bodyText:
With the single slot design, the ResolveCHK will be on the load of side table entry, i.e. the trees will look like
ResolveCHK
  aload <CallSiteTableEntry @<callSiteIndex>>
treetop
  aloadi <appendix object>  // array-shadow from CallSiteTableEntry
  ...
treetop
  aloadi <memberNameObject>  // array-shadow from CallSiteTableEntry
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -3273,6 +3273,45 @@ TR_J9ByteCodeIlGenerator::genInvokeDynamic(int32_t callSiteIndex)
 
    if (comp()->getOption(TR_FullSpeedDebug) && !isPeekingMethod())
       comp()->failCompilation<J9::FSDHasInvokeHandle>("FSD_HAS_INVOKEHANDLE 0");
+#if defined(J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE)
+
+   // Call generated when call site table entry is resolved:
+   // -----------------------------------------------------
+   // call <target method obtained from memberName object>
+   //    arg0
+   //    arg1
+   //    ...
+   //    aloadi <appendix object>
+   // ------------------------------------------------------
+   // Call generated when call site table entry is unresolved:
+   // ------------------------------------------------------
+   // ResolveCHK

nodes.bodyText: @dmitry-ten Should this query be guarded by J9VM_OPT_JITSERVER macro?

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -3311,6 +3354,48 @@ TR_J9ByteCodeIlGenerator::genInvokeHandle(int32_t cpIndex)
 
    if (comp()->getOption(TR_FullSpeedDebug) && !isPeekingMethod())
       comp()->failCompilation<J9::FSDHasInvokeHandle>("FSD_HAS_INVOKEHANDLE 1");
+#if defined(J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE)
+   // Call generated when methodType table entry is resolved:
+   // -----------------------------------------------------
+   // call <target method obtained from memberName object>
+   //    aload  <Ljava/lang/invoke/MethodHandle;>
+   //    arg0
+   //    arg1
+   //    ...
+   //    aloadi <appendix object>
+   // ------------------------------------------------------
+   // Call generated when methodType table entry is unresolved:
+   // ------------------------------------------------------
+   // ResolveCHK
+   //    aload <CallSiteTableEntry @<callSiteIndex>>
